results.title: [Mental Hygiene Authority 1961]
results.brief_description:
This film was made by the Mental Hygiene Authority of Victoria (later the Mental Health Authority), of which psychiatrist Eric Cunningham Dax was the inaugural Chairman. Dax was an advocate for greater community engagement with mental health and the introduction of art and education programs within psychiatric care. During his tenure, he implemented widespread reform of mental health institutions.

This film shows scenes at the Oakleigh Retarded Childrens Centre, the Oakleigh Sheltered Workshop and the Larundel Psychiatric Hospital. In the film, we see developmentally and intellectually disabled children and adults engaged in activities in the centres including learning how to weave using looms and working on items such as shoelaces and hubcaps in workshop environements. We also see patients of the psychiatric hospital working and playing table tennis.

results.title: [District Nursing Appeal]
results.brief_description:
The Royal District Nursing Service was founded in 1885 and was originally called the Melbourne District Nursing Service. An initiative led by the Reverend Charles Strong, the organisation was established to nurse the sick, poor and disadvantaged in their own homes. By the early 1920s the nurses were treating 25,000 patients per year and had established a convalescent institution, the After-Care Home (later Hospital) in Collingwood. In 1966 the organisation became the Royal District Nursing Service.

In this television appeal from 1967, Graham Kennedy presents a feature on behalf of the Royal District Nursing Service. The film includes footage of Kennedy in the television studio, appealing for door knockers to help fundraise for the organisation. The program shows footage of Kennedy interviewing an elderly war veteran at his home in Albert Park, who lives alone and is visited by an RDNS nurse every day.

It appears this film was produced as a Kinescope - a 16mm film recording of a live television broadcast. As such, both the sound and image are a little ‘muddy’ as is typical of this technology.

results.title: [Melbourne District Nursing Service Centre Openings]
results.brief_description:
The Royal District Nursing Service was founded in 1885 and was originally called the Melbourne District Nursing Service. An initiative led by the Reverend Charles Strong, the organisation was established to nurse the sick, poor and disadvantaged in their own homes. By the early 1920s the nurses were treating 25,000 patients per year and had established a convalescent institution, the After-Care Home (later Hospital) in Collingwood. In 1966 the organisation became the Royal District Nursing Service.

This film captures the opening of two Melbourne District Nursing Service centres in Melbourne in 1964 and 1965 and an event celebrating the renaming of the organisation to the Royal District Nursing Service in 1966. The film features great footage of 1960s nursing equipment, uniforms, fashions of the period, architecture and interiors of the centres and procedures for nursing visits.

The first ceremony takes place on 28th February 1964 and features an opening speech by Lady Delacombe, the wife of Sir Rohan Delacombe, Governor of Victoria. The camera focuses on several photographs on the walls of the centre - including the first two nurses of the MDNS, Nurse Ferguson and Nurse Cannon; nurses in Victorian era uniform on bicycles; and nurses in the 1920s wearing pith helmets with red Maltese cross.

The opening of the Footscray Centre takes place on 5th April 1965 and the proceedings are opened by the Minister for Health, R. W. Mack. The final section of film shows an event celebrating renaming the organisation the Royal District Nursing Service, in 1966.

results.title: [Cinesound Review 1950-1965]
results.brief_description:
This film contains excerpts from Cinesound Review, a news broadcast that covered significant social, cultural and political events in Australia. The film features a number of different clips from newsreels between 1950 and 1965.

The first section, titled ‘1950 Melbourne Cup’, shows the horse race at Flemington Racecourse, photographed by Ron Horner. The film includes close-ups of people in the crowd, and commentary of the race as Comic Court wins. This is followed by a section titled ‘Scone Rodeo: Bronchos (sic) on the Bust’, featuring footage of a horse rodeo in Scone, New South Wales.

The third section, titled ‘Fur Flies: Battling Budgerigar K.O.’s Cat’ features a playfight between two pets, a ginger cat and a budgerigar. In the fourth section we see ANZAC Day parades in Melbourne and Sydney, preluded by the title ‘ANZAC: Nation’s Homage’.

The fifth section is titled ‘Skiing: Day and Night Fun at Mt. Buller’, with commentary by David Low. It features children learning how to ski and social activities in the resorts, including bands and dancing. This is followed by an excerpt called ‘Clark Well Ahead’, showing the motorcar race at the 1965 British Grand Prix, won by Jim Clark.

The film ends with a cartoon called ‘Local Boy Makes Good: A Story with a Moral’ and three feature film trailers: ‘The Counterfeit Traitor’ (1962), ‘Pollyanna’ (1960) and ‘Mein Kampf’ (1960).

results.title: [Cinesound Review: Royal Tour Concludes]
results.brief_description:
This film is a Cinesound Review, a news broadcast that covered significant social, cultural and political events in Australia. The newsreel shows the final leg of the 1970 Royal Tour with Queen Elizabeth II, Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh and Princess Anne, for the bicentenary celebrations of the arrival of Captain James Cook in Australia in 1770.

The film shows the royal family arriving in Brisbane, Queensland, on the Royal Yacht Britannia, where they are greeted by crowds of people in hundreds of boats on the river. It shows the family attending various events, including a welcome at Parliament House, theatre shows and a children’s parade at Lang Park, or Brisbane Stadium.

Princess Anne visits a sheep station at Cunnamulla, Queensland, while Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip visit the mines at Mount Isa, Queensland.

The film shows bicentenary celebrations in Cooktown, Queensland, and Botany Bay, New South Wales. These celebrations include a speech by the Queen and re-enactments of Captain James Cook’s arrival in Australia in 1770, with interactions with Aboriginal Australian people.

The film continues with fireworks over Sydney Harbour; an ANZAC Day march in Canberra, Australian Capital Territory; Prince Philip playing polo with a local team; and the opening of the international terminal at Sydney Airport, from which the royal family departs.

results.title: [Around Australia with Movietone; Gt. Barrier Reef; Sporting Highlights; Skiing; 1949 Melbourne Cup]
results.brief_description:
This film is a Movietone Newsreel, a theatrical news broadcast that covered significant social, cultural and political events in Australia. This newsreel consists of five sections, covering news and events around Australia in 1949.

The first section, titled ‘Around Australia with Movietone’, photographed by J. W. Trerise shows pearl divers in Darwin, Northern Territory. The film takes place on a Japanese lugger, featuring Japanese divers and Peter Nakashiba, an interpreter and advisor to the Japanese in Darwin. It shows the protective diving suits and apparatus worn by pearl divers.

The second section is titled ‘Gt Barrier Reef’ and shows people fishing from trawlers on the Great Barrier Reef. The narrator describes the fishing as a popular sport and names the type of fish, including Spanish mackerel.

In the third section, ‘Sporting Highlights’, we see a horse rodeo in Warwick, Queensland, with commentary by Jack Davey, a popular radio entertainer who narrated Movietone News reels from the 1930s to 1950s.

The fourth section is titled ‘Skiing’, and takes place at Mount Kosciuszko, showing the ski fields and resort as a popular tourist destination. It includes footage of George Day, the manager of the Chalet at Charlotte Pass and a renowned Australian skier.

The final section, titled ‘1949 Melbourne Cup’, shows the popular horse racing event at Flemington Race Course, Melbourne, which in 1949 was won by Foxzami.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 26]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is situated in the Victorian Alpine Region in the summer months when the only snows are at the very top of the mountains. Wallace focuses on the roads that wind, at times dramatically, through the mountain range as well as the surrounding landscape of trees, rocks and waterways.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 titles ‘WHC Presents’, ‘The Victorian Alps’
00:00:50:00 views from the road and a small old house
00:01:06:00 sign ‘Alpine Road’ with lots of information for the traveller
00:01:25:00 sign ‘You are now entering Mount Hotham Alpine Reserve’
00:01:35:00 looking across a corner of a dirt road high up in the mountains
00:02:22:00 roads, signs and aerials on top of the mountains and a melting snowman
00:02:58:00 brass sundial
00:04:46:00 sign warning to ‘keep to the left of the poles’ and directional sign to ‘Hotham, Diamentina, Harrietville’
00:05:20:00 chair lift pulley station and 1970s style four wheel drive vehicle, a chalet and hamlet
00:05:55:00 a small A-frame chalet or hut
00:06:30:00 views of roads, trees and cars with the mountains in the background
00:07:05:00 two purple swamp hens (common to wetlands or rivers of Eastern Australia)
00:07:50:00 signs ‘Mount Buffalo’ and ‘Eurobin Falls’ followed by views of cascading waters over rocky embankments and cliffs
00:08:30:00 sign ‘Mackeys Lookout’ followed by views out over the valleys below including cars negotiating the tight turns on the roads winding down the mountain
00:09:08:00 sign ‘Rollarson’s Falls’
00:09:35:00 hikers negotiate logs and rocks along the path
00:10:16:00 a long narrow waterfall into a lovely natural rock pool
00:11:00:00 looking out over misty valleys through an old walk bridge
00:13:08:00 a narrow waterfall in a rocky cliffface
00:13:36:00 snow along the sides of the road
00:14:26:00 sign ‘Toownag Gap, Mt Buffalo, Mt Bogong’ and a visitor looking through binoculars from a lookout
00:14:46:00 looking down from a higher vantage spot on a long windy road through the mountains toward a township beyond
00:15:20:00 views of electricity towers across the ranges
00:15:50:00 sign ‘Pretty Valley Branch East Kiewa River’
00:16:11:00 sign ‘rocky Valley Dam’ and scenes around the dam
00:17:05:00 sign ‘Strawberry Saddle’ followed by a mob of emus
00:18:07:00 sign ‘Bundara River’ in the Victorian Alpine Region
00:19:50:00 sign ‘Omeo’, Victoria, followed by an older style cattle truck travelling along a street and the Public Telegraph Office in the township
results.description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is situated in the Victorian Alpine Region in the summer months when the only snows are at the very top of the mountains. Wallace focuses on the roads that wind, at times dramatically, through the mountain range as well as the surrounding landscape of trees, rocks and waterways.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 25]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film captures a trip along the ‘Great Ocean Road’ in Victoria. The Great Ocean Road is an Australian National Heritage listed 243 kilometres stretch of road along the south-eastern coast of Victoria between Torquay and Allansford near Warrnambool. The film features many scenes of the ocean, coastal walks, rock formations such as the Twelve Apostles, and seaside towns.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:12:00 title cards ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘The Ocean Road’, ‘Filmed by WHC’
00:01:01:00 woman walking down a path from the lighthouse at Airey’s Inlet
00:01:14:00 the historic ‘Great Ocean Road’ sign over the highway
00:01:27:00 sign for ‘Cinema Point lookout’ with vintage car in foreground
00:05:06:00 the Twelve Apostles
00:09:20:00 two people at a lookout
00:12:00:00 woman lying on the ground with a camera
00:14:50:00 boats in a bay
00:16:31:00 a small harbour
00:17:38:00 a bluestone church, likely St John’s in Port Fairy
00:017:57:00 the Yambuk Inn in Port Fairy
00:19:42:00 an emu running down the road
00:19:57:00 two women comparing sticks for walking
00:23:42:00 a jetty by a river
00:24:40:00 sunset over the water
00:25:01:00 title card ‘The End’

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 20]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film shows a trip to Papua New Guinea in 1961. The filmmaker captures a seaside town, fishing boats, people at a market and men in traditional headdresses, as well as the Boumana (Bomana) War Cemetery in Port Moresby.

Selected highlights list:
00:01:27:00 fishing boats by the sea
00:02:05:00 group of women sitting around talking
00:03:19:00 young child
00:04:21:00 boats in the bay
00:05:21:00 sign for ‘Boumana War Cemetery’
00:06:45:00 views across a valley
00:07:04:00 a waterfall
00:09:05:00 men in headdresses
00:09:16:00 a polo game with locals watching
00:10:57:00 views over the bay
00:12:44:00 girls playing a ball game
00:13:15:00 man fixing a small boat
00:14:00:00 a traffic warden in the middle of an intersection
00:15:16:00 views from an aeroplane

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 19]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film showcases Papua New Guinea (PNG) in the 1960s. It begins with coastal towns and ports, sighing, canoes and boats and then travels by plane to the ‘Highlands’ on what appears to be a cargo plane. Along the way, Wallace captures the villages, the dramatic landscapes and the various peoples of PNG.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 a group of smiling children walk along a road under palm trees
00:00:25:00 thatched houses facing a lagoon
00:01:45:00 taking down the sail on a local ‘outrigger canoe’
00:02:18:00 view from a plane overhead and a TAA (Trans Australia Airlines) plane on an airfield being emptied of cargo
00:02:32:00 several totem sculptures and carved statues
00:02:57:00 a man spearing fish in the waves off a rocky perch
00:03:09:00 Coastwatchers Memorial in Madang
00:03:18:00 ‘Petrus II’ sailing boat and unloading cargo of cacao beans in large hessian sacks from a boat onto a pier
00:03:54:00 a lovely old rusty shed, jetty and boats in a palm tree setting
00:04:04:00 school girls playing sport
00:04:29:00 fixing a car in a village of thatch covered houses
00:05:04:00 canoes being paddled across the water
00:06:07:00 a larger boat followed by scenes around a portside town
00:07:34:00 a particularly picturesque roadside store, Central Merchants, and people carrying goods on shoulders and heads
00:08:34:00 ‘44 gallon drums’ being unloaded from a plane by being bounced onto a large rubber tyre
00:08:54:00 aeriel views over the jungles and mountains and misty clouds
00:09:24:00 a long winding river being filmed from the plane above
00:11:29:00 boarding a TAA plane and takeoff with the mountains in the background
00:12:04:00 a small yellow plane
00:12:08:00 a village with thatched houses
00:12:50:00 small planes
00:13:00:00 traditional dress
00:13:23:00 flying over mountains and looking at roads criss-crossing the terrain
00:19:38:00 traditional grass mat weaving
00:21:53:00 sign ‘Kainantu Mile High Gateway to the Highlands Alt. 5280’
00:22:21:00 a large river system from overhead
00:22:10:00 a signpost for ‘Mumeng’, ‘Bulolo’ and ‘Wau’
00:23:38:00 lush valleys in the Highlands
00:25:44:00 sign ‘You are now approaching Wau, Top of Drome, Elvn 3200’
00:28:58:00 house in the trees
00:29:11:00 people washing clothes in the river
00:30:10:00 a cemetery and white crucifix monuments
00:31:04:00 TAA plane

00:31:04:00 TAA plane
description_for_label:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film showcases Papua New Guinea (PNG) in the 1960s. It begins with coastal towns and ports, sighing, canoes and boats and then travels by plane to the ‘Highlands’ on what appears to be a cargo plane. Along the way, Wallace captures the villages, the dramatic landscapes and the various peoples of PNG.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 a group of smiling children walk along a road under palm trees
00:00:25:00 thatched houses facing a lagoon
00:01:45:00 taking down the sail on a local ‘outrigger canoe’
00:02:18:00 view from a plane overhead and a TAA (Trans Australia Airlines) plane on an airfield being emptied of cargo
00:02:32:00 several totem sculptures and carved statues
00:02:57:00 a man spearing fish in the waves off a rocky perch
00:03:09:00 Coastwatchers Memorial in Madang
00:03:18:00 ‘Petrus II’ sailing boat and unloading cargo of cacao beans in large hessian sacks from a boat onto a pier
00:03:54:00 a lovely old rusty shed, jetty and boats in a palm tree setting
00:04:04:00 school girls playing sport
00:04:29:00 fixing a car in a village of thatch covered houses
00:05:04:00 canoes being paddled across the water
00:06:07:00 a larger boat followed by scenes around a portside town
00:07:34:00 a particularly picturesque roadside store, Central Merchants, and people carrying goods on shoulders and heads
00:08:34:00 ‘44 gallon drums’ being unloaded from a plane by being bounced onto a large rubber tyre
00:08:54:00 aeriel views over the jungles and mountains and misty clouds
00:09:24:00 a long winding river being filmed from the plane above
00:11:29:00 boarding a TAA plane and takeoff with the mountains in the background
00:12:04:00 a small yellow plane
00:12:08:00 a village with thatched houses
00:12:50:00 small planes
00:13:00:00 traditional dress
00:13:23:00 flying over mountains and looking at roads criss-crossing the terrain
00:19:38:00 traditional grass mat weaving
00:21:53:00 sign ‘Kainantu Mile High Gateway to the Highlands Alt. 5280’
00:22:21:00 a large river system from overhead
00:22:10:00 a signpost for ‘Mumeng’, ‘Bulolo’ and ‘Wau’
00:23:38:00 lush valleys in the Highlands
00:25:44:00 sign ‘You are now approaching Wau, Top of Drome, Elvn 3200’
00:28:58:00 house in the trees
00:29:11:00 people washing clothes in the river
00:30:10:00 a cemetery and white crucifix monuments
00:31:04:00 TAA plane
